Adachi is a former [[police]] officer from the Kanagawa Prefecture. He seeks the help of [[Kasuga Ichiban]] as Adachi needs Kasuga's connections in order to help expose corruption within the police force.

Voiced by:
[[Ootsuka Akio]] (Japanese)
Andrew Morgado (English)

title: makimura_makoto
body:
A character that appears in [i][[Ryuu Ga Gotoku 0]][/i] as a major character and in [i][[Ryuu Ga Gotoku 2|Ryuu Ga Gotoku Kiwami 2]][/i] as a cameo.

She is a blind woman who meets [[Majima Goro]] when he attempts to assassinate her, but instead Majima resolves in trying to protect her from danger instead.

Voiced by [[Sawashiro Miyuki]].

title: majima_everywhere
body:
[[Ryuu ga Gotoku Kiwami]]'s game-specific mechanic, featuring [[Majima Goro]] ambushing protagonist [[Kiryu Kazuma]] in the most unlikely of places while wearing the most unlikely of costumes in order to "hone Kiryuu-chan's fighting skills".

The sheer absurdity of the above scenarios has led to it being memed among the Japanese and later global fanbase. Depictions of such will usually involve Majima popping out of a manhole, Majima wearing a police uniform, Majima crossdressing in a cabaret hostess or female idol costume, or Majima breaking a wall or door and entering a room [[Kool-Aid Man]]-style. Shouting "Kiryuu-chan!" optional but highly recommended.

This is also sometimes parodied using other characters in place of Majima. These will usually involve the "popping out of a manhole" variant, with said character lifting up the manhole cover with one arm while making a "shielding one's eyes to look far ahead" gesture, both in imitation of Majima's pose. Accompanied by their "title" and name as a caption. The character will also often suggest sage(-sounding) advice to another character while doing so.

title: date_makoto
body:
A recurring character in the [i][[Ryuu ga Gotoku (series)|]][/i] series. 

Date is a police detective who had a falling out with his family thanks to the events that involved [[Kiryu Kazuma]] prior to [i][[Ryuu ga Gotoku 1]][/i] and seeks to find the truth behind them. He helps [[Kiryu Kazuma|Kiryuu]] throughout the game and soon becomes one of his closest allies in the series.

Voiced by:
Yamaji Kazuhiro (Japanese)
Bill Farmer (English)

title: nishikiyama_akira
body:
A major character in the [i][[Ryuu ga Gotoku (series)|]][/i] series, appearing in [i][[Ryuu ga Gotoku 1]][/i] and [i][[Ryuu ga Gotoku 0]][/i].

Nishikiyama is the sworn brother of his childhood friend, [[Kiryu Kazuma]]. He has a lively and loyal personality but under the surface, harbors a huge inferiority complex. However, after Kiryuu's imprisonment, he became power-hungry and ambitious which eventually resulted in his betrayal of those once close to him.

Voiced by:
Nakaya Kazuhiro (Japanese)
Michael Rosenbaum (English)

title: kasuga_ichiban
body:
The protagonist of the [i][[Ryuu Ga Gotoku (series)|]][/i] series, succeeding [[Kiryu Kazuma]] from [i][[Ryuu Ga Gotoku 7]][/i] onwards.

A former member of the Arakawa Family, Kasuga is a passionate and out-spoken bottom-barrel [[yakuza]] with a strong sense of justice who lived most of his younger days playing [i][[Dragon Quest]][/i]. Because of this, he imagines every fight as a RPG battle and relies on teamwork with his friends in order to fight stronger opponents.

Voiced by:
Nakaya Kazuhiro (Japanese)
Kaiji Tang (English)

title: ryuu_ga_gotoku_3
body:
The third main installment of the Ryuu ga Gotoku series.

[[Kiryu Kazuma]] and his adoptive daughter, [[Sawamura Haruka]] move to Okinawa to run an orphanage and to leave behind Kiryuu's yakuza ties. However, he becomes involved once his orphanage is at risk of being demolished as it is on land required for government plans. While in Okinawa, Kiryuu befriends [[Shimabukuro Rikiya]] of the local Ryuudou Family.

Also known as:
[i]Yakuza 3[/i]

title: akiyama_shun
body:
A recurring [i][[Ryuu ga Gotoku (series)|]][/i] character that debuted in [i][[Ryuu ga Gotoku 4]][/i] and returns in [i][[Ryuu ga Gotoku 5]][/i] as a playable protagonist. He is moneylender nicknamed "The Lifeline of Kamurocho". He originally was a banker until he became homeless due to being framed for a money embezzlement scheme. However, the events of [i][[Ryuu ga Gotoku 1]][/i] where [spoiler]the explosion of the Millennium Tower scattered large amounts of yen[/spoiler] allowed Akiyama to invest his money to build a fortune.

Akiyama generally has a very laidback, unprofessional and disorganised personality, much to the chagrin of his secretary. He soon becomes a very close ally to [[Kiryu Kazuma]], even helping his adoptive daughter [[Sawamura Haruka]] investigate and traverse across the dangerous idol industry in Osaka. His fighting style revolves around sharp, rapid and swift kicks.

He is voiced by [[Yamadera Kouichi]].

title: kuze_daisaku
body:
A character in the [i][[Ryuu ga Gotoku (series)|]][/i] series, he appears as a major antagonist in [i][[Ryuu ga Gotoku 0]][/i].

One of the three lieutenants of the Toujou Clan's Dojima Family, Kuze is infamous for his tenacity and determination. He continuously appears as an adversary to main character, [[Kiryu Kazuma]] throughout [i][[Ryuu ga Gotoku 0]][/i]'s story. His fighting style consists of boxing and rare kick attacks.

Portrayed by:
Ozawa Hitoshi

title: ryuu_ga_gotoku_4
body:
Fourth main installment of the [i][[Ryuu Ga Gotoku (series)|]][/i] series.

This is the first time where multiple protagonists appear in the games alongside [[Kiryu Kazuma]].
The other protagonists are [[Akiyama Shun]], [[Saejima Taiga]] and [[Tanimura Masayoshi]].

The game has the four protagonists trying to decipher an event that happened 25 years ago that recently resurfaced as tensions among yakuza clans begin to appear.

Also known as:
[i]Ryuu Ga Gotoku 4: Densetsu o Tsugumono[/i] ([i]Like a Dragon 4: Successor of a Legend[/i]
[i]Yakuza 4[/i]

title: kuroda_takaya
body: [[Real life|Real-life]] Japanese voice actor. Most famous for voicing [[Kiryu Kazuma]] in the [[Ryuu ga Gotoku (series)|]] (AKA [i]Yakuza[/i]) series of video games.

title: ryuu_ga_gotoku_1
body:
The first main installment of the [i][[Ryuu ga Gotoku (series)|]][/i] series.

After spending 10 years in prison for taking the fall of a murder committed by his [[Nishikiyama Akira|best friend]], former yakuza, [[Kiryu Kazuma]] tries to investigate the events that transpired while he was absent. While investigating, he meets allies such as police detective, [[Date Makoto]] and a child linked to one of Kiryuu's childhood friends, [[Sawamura Haruka]].

Received a remake in 2016 in the [i][[Ryuu ga Gotoku 0]][/i] engine, titled [i][[Ryuu ga Gotoku Kiwami]][/i]. 

Also known as:
[i]Yakuza[/i]
[i]Yakuza Kiwami[/i]

title: ryuu_ga_gotoku_5
body:
The fifth main installment of the [i][[Ryuu Ga Gotoku (series)|]][/i] series.

It features five protagonists, [[Kiryu Kazuma]], [[Akiyama Shun]], [[Sawamura Haruka]], [[Saejima Taiga]] and [[Shinada Tatsuo]].

The five protagonists become involved in an all-out [[yakuza]] war, spanning from Fukuoka, Sapporo, Nagoya, Osaka and Tokyo.

Also known as:
[i]Ryuu Ga Gotoku 5: Yume, Kanaeshi Mono[/i] ([i]Like a Dragon 5: Fulfiller of Dreams[/i])
[i]Yakuza 5[/i]

Although Libeccio is not the nameship of her class, she was the first of her class introduced into the game. [[Maestrale (kancolle)|]], [[Grecale (kancolle)|]], and [[Scirocco (kancolle)|]], who started appearing in the game much, much later, wear otherwise identical uniforms as Libeccio. Therefore, this tag would be an umbrella tag for cosplays of any Maestrale-class girl unless there are visual cues or commentary specific to either Maestrale, Grecale, or Scirocco.

title: gemerl
body:
Character from the [[sonic_(series)|Sonic the Hedgehog]] series. A black and yellow [[robot]] created by [[Dr. Eggman]] after analyzing the data of [[emerl_(sonic)|Emerl]], a similar robot that was destroyed during the events of [[Sonic Battle]]. He would incorporate Gemerl in his mechs while facing off against [[sonic_the_hedgehog|Sonic]] and his friends in [[Sonic Advance 3]].

After the robot suddenly decides on its own to use the energy of the [[chaos_emerald|Chaos Emeralds]], Eggman temporarily joins hands with Sonic, then transformed into [[Super Sonic]] to stop it. Gemerl is eventually repaired and reprogrammed by [[tails_(sonic)|Tails]], and starts to live with [[Cream the Rabbit]] and her [[vanilla_the_rabbit|mother]].

title: they're_not_panties
body:
"They're not [[panties]], so it's not embarrassing!"

A "booster" line in [[Strike Witches]] wherein the speaker tells the listeners to forget that their [[underwear]] is exposed or treat their underwear as if they are "working" attire, or wearing something over them, probably to put their focus on their job instead.

The line is a self-aware joke about the premise of the series, in which the "witches" - various female pilots of a [[striker unit]] combat gear - do not wear anything on their bottom but their [[panties]], which is explained in-universe as to prevent their clothing from tangling with their striker unit.

Possibly said by [[Miyafuji Yoshika]] as she wears a [[school swimsuit]] [[swimsuit_under_clothes|underneath her uniform]] and technically not underwear.
other_names: パンツじゃないから恥ずかしくないもん!

title: shochuumimai
body:
Shochuumimai (or shochuu o-mimai) are postcards that people in Japan send to friends during midsummer. They typically contain the phrase "暑中(お)見舞い申し上げます" (shochuu (o-)mimai moushi agemasu), which means something like "seeing how you're doing this midsummer".

h4. See also

* [[zanshomimai]] (late summer)
* [[kanchuumimai]] (mid winter)

title: world_witches_series
body:
A mixed-media project originally created by [[Shimada Fumikane]] via a series of magazine illustration columns.

The series revolves around an alternate universe [[World War II]] scenario, and features various characters based on [[genderswap|genderswapped]] [[real life]] ace pilots dubbed "witches", donning a magic-powered gear called [[striker unit]] based on combat aircraft of that era.

h4. Tagging

If a character appeared in either the [[Strike Witches]] or [[Brave Witches]] series, even if they are not a part of the 501st or 502nd Joint Fighter squadrons, then the corresponding [b]Strike Witches[/b] or [b]Brave Witches[/b] tag should be added.

One caveat to this is...

* If a character from another unit or squadron that appeared in the anime/movie 
* Also appears with other members of their unit that did not appear in the anime/movie
* With none of the 501st/502nd members present

... they would not get tagged [[Strike Witches]]/[[Brave Witches]].

h4. Series

* [[Strike Witches: Suomus Misfits Squadron]]
* [[Strike Witches]]
* [[Tenkuu no Otome-tachi]]
* [[Witches Of Africa]]
* [[Strike Witches Zero]]
* [[Strike Witches: Katayoku no Majo-tachi]]
* [[Strike Witches: Kurenai no Majo-tachi]]
* [[Strike Witches: Aurora no Majo]]
* [[Noble Witches]]
* [[Brave Witches]]
* [[Luminous Witches]]

h4. See also
* [[They're not panties]]
* [[List of World Witches Series characters]]

title: time_lapse
body:
An image showing how something changes or the progression of an event overtime through the use of several “frames”. A considerate amount of time may pass between individual frames, making this tag different from [[sequential]] (in which at most seconds pass).

Usually, other than the main subject that is changing, the rest of the frames should remain mostly the same. (Ex: for a time lapse of a store, the angle/position at which the store is displayed in each panel is the same).

For the time-lapse of a work being drawn, see [[making-of]].

h4. See Also
* [[Progression]]
* [[fixed-point camera]]

title: fixed-point_camera
body:

title: sega_dreamcast
body:
[[SEGA]]'s final [[video game]] [[game_console|home console]] produced for the sixth-generation market of consoles. It was released in November 1998 in Japan and later in September 1999 in other territories. 

Sega ultimately had to withdraw from the console market when it couldn't compete against [[Sony]]'s [[Playstation 2]] and [[Nintendo]]'s [[Gamecube]], instead sticking to producing games. The company discontinued the Dreamcast in North America early in March 2001, but support for the system continued in Europe and Oceania until the end of 2002. In Japan consoles were still sold until 2007 and new licensed games continued to be released some time later. 10.6 million units were sold worldwide, as of 2002.

The [b]Dreamcast[/b] is still fondly remembered for several revolutionary games and pioneering home [[game_console|console]] online gaming.

h4.See also
* [[List of game consoles]]
* [[Tag Group:Video Game]]
* [[VMU]]

title: sega_sg-1000_ii
body:
The [b]SG-1000 Mark II[/b] (エスジー・セン [i]Esujī Sen II[/i]), also known as the [b]Sega Game 1000 Mark II[/b], was a cartridge based [[video game]] home [[game_console|console]] manufactured by [[Sega]] and released in Japan, Australia, and other countries in the early 80s. 

The console was released in July 1984 as an improved version of the original [[Sega SG-1000]] console from a year before. It featured a few hardware tweaks from the original model, including detachable [[gamepad]]s and the ability to play Sega Card games. 

The Mark II did not sell well, however, leading to Sega's decision to continue work on its video game hardware. This would result in the release of the [[Sega Mark III]] in Japan in 1985, which later became the [[Sega Master System]] worldwide.
h4. See also
* [[List of game consoles]]

title: sega_sg-1000
body:
The [b]SG-1000[/b], also known as the [b]Sega Game 1000[/b], was a cartridge based [[video game]] [[game console|home console]] manufactured by [[Sega]] and released in Japan, Australia, and other countries in the early 80s. 

This system marked Sega's first entry into the home video game hardware business, and provided the basis for the more successful [[Sega Master System]]. 

It was first introduced in July 15, 1983. The SG-1000 was released on the same day that [[Nintendo]] released the [[Famicom]] in Japan. The console was developed in response to a downturn in arcades in 1982. The SG-1000 is not well remembered due to its poor performance, but served a role in the development of future Sega consoles.

The system was released in several forms, including the [[Sega SC-3000]] computer and the redesigned [[Sega SG-1000 II]], released a year later.

h4. See also
* [[List of game consoles]]
h4. External links

* "Wikipedia: SG-1000":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SG-1000

title: atari_2600
body:
The [b]Atari 2600[/b], also known as the [b]Atari VCS[/b] ([b]Atari Video Computer System[/b]) before November 1982, is an old and classic home [[game console]] by [[Atari]], Inc. Released on September 11, 1977. It is credited with popularizing the use of microprocessor-based hardware and ROM [[game cartridge]]s containing [[video game]] code, a format first used with the [i]Fairchild Channel F[/i] video game console in 1976. 

This format contrasts with the older model of having non-microprocessor dedicated hardware, which could only play the games that were physically built into the unit (like in very early [[Pong]] game consoles).

The 2600 was a black and wood colored console typically bundled with [[television]] connectors and power [[cable]]s, two joystick [[game controller]]s, a conjoined pair of paddle controllers, and a game cartridge (initially "Combat", and later "[[pac-man_(game)|Pac-Man]]"). 

It was a very popular and successful machine. However, due to a cheap loyalty fee (that any game makers must paid to console owners for making a game for their system) and lack of quality control, the Atari 2600 was flooded with countless shovelwares that started to destroy its reputation. 

The release of the infamous [[E.T.]] video game (which Atari rushed in its development and produced too many copies of it for sale) it was later one of the causes for the subsequent "North America video game crash of 1983":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_game_crash_of_1983 , after which the system's popularity diminished greatly. By 1985 it was all but forgotten, but this paved the way for the introduction of more advanced and popular consoles like the [[Nintendo]] [[Famicom]] ([[NES]]) in the mid 80s.  

h4. Rival consoles from its era

* [[Intellivision]]
* [[ColecoVision]]
h4. See also
* [[List of game consoles]]

body:

An Acquaint Fate is dark blue, and has a spherical cage joined together by a six-pointed flower surrounding a spiked core.

title: oceanid_(genshin_impact)
body:
An enemy in [[Genshin Impact]].

A lifeform created from highly pure, condensed Hydro elements. They are often attached to bodies of water, and can create [[hydro_mimic_(genshin_impact)|Hydro mimics]] to fight for them.

Oceanids are capable of flight. Their body consists of a head with a singular white orb in it, a fish-like body with two three-pointed fins, and a forked tail fin. Most of their body is light blue, except for some darker patterns on the bases of their fins and white adornments wrapping around the head.

title: hydro_eidolon_(genshin_impact)
body:
A creature in [[genshin_impact|Genshin Impact]].

Hydro lifeforms found within the Veluriyam Mirage who are capable of transforming into various objects. They cannot speak, but often use emote icons to represent how they're feeling.

A Hydro Eidolon's body consists of three main spheres of water: one large central sphere, and two smaller spheres at its sides. An Eidolon may also transfer smaller drops of water between its lesser spheres and its central sphere while moving. An Eidolon has a large, single eye on its central sphere.

title: asagiri_youko
body:
朝霧 陽子 (あさぎり ようこ)

The main heroine of [[Genmu Senki Leda]], who writes a song that inadvertently acts as a bridge between Earth and its parallel world Ashanti. The overlord [[zell (genmu senki leda)|Zell]] wants to conquer Earth using this bridge, but the legendary warrior Leda prophesied Youko's arrival and gives her the ability to become a warrior.

She has [[long hair|long]] [[red hair]] kept in a [[side ponytail]] and wears metallic blue [[bikini armor]].

body:

title: marquee_lights
body:
A line or grid of [[light_bulb|lightbulbs]]. Often flashing intermittently or in a chasing pattern to guide the attention of a viewer in a specific direction.
These can be used as a sign themselves (like an animated arrow, or glowing letters), around the outside border of a sign, or as decoration on and around the entrances of large buildings like hotels, theatres, casinos, and train stations.

Very commonly seen in [[circus]] and [[movie_theater|movie theater]] aesthetics, or as the lightbulbs around the [[mirror]] of a [[vanity_table|vanity table]].

h4. External links

* https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marquee_(structure)

title: chocolate_tart

Because of its egg-based filling, it is considered a type of custard [[tart (food)|]]. This dish is similar to chocolate [[mousse (food)|]], but the baking process gives the chocolate tart a firmer texture.

title: makizushi
body:
[b]Makizushi[/b] (巻き寿司, lit. "rolled sushi") is a type of long cylindrical [[sushi]], usually rolled in [[nori (seaweed)]] sheets. A thick roll is called 太巻き ([i]Futomaki[/i]) and a thin roll is called 細巻き ([i]Hosomaki[/i]). For posts where the seaweed is on the inside of the roll, see [[uramaki]].

Normally makizushi are cut into several pieces, but uncut rolls of makizushi are eaten as [[ehoumaki]].

Makizushi is often portrayed as a [[phallic symbol]] and used to perform [[simulated fellatio]].

h4. See also

* [[sushi]]
* [[Tag group:Food Tags]]

h4. External links

* "Wikipedia: Makizushi":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sushi#Makizushi

title: sata_andagi
body:
Sata andagi (sātā andāgī) are sweet deep fried buns of dough similar to doughnuts (or the Portuguese malasada, or the Dutch oliebollen), native to the Japanese prefecture of Okinawa. They are also popular in Hawaii, sometimes known there simply as andagi. Traditional Okinawan andagi is made by mixing flour, sugar and eggs. The ingredients are mixed into a ball and deep fried.

Saataa means "sugar", while andaagii means "deep fried" ("oil" (anda) + "fried" (agii)) in Okinawan (satō and abura-age in Japanese.) It is also known as saataa andagii and saataa anragii.

Sata andagi are a part of Okinawan cuisine. Like most confectionery from the Ryukyu Islands, the techniques for making them are descended from a combination of Chinese and Japanese techniques, They are typically prepared so that the outside is crispy and browned while the inside is light and cake-like.

h4. External links
* "Wikipedia: Sata andagi":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sata_andagi]
* "Wikipedia (Japanese): サーターアンダーギー":[https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E3%82%B5%E3%83%BC%E3%82%BF%E3%83%BC%E3%82%A2%E3%83%B3%E3%83%80%E3%83%BC%E3%82%AE%E3%83%BC]

title: tiffin_carrier
body:
A kind of [[lunchbox]] used widely in Asia and the Caribbean.  Composed of 2-4 circular containers stacked atop each other and held together with a handle that runs down the sides of the containers, which can be detached from the sides when separating everything.  Similar to stacked [[bento]] boxes, the bottom container is frequently larger than the other containers and usually contains rice.

h4. External links

* "Wikipedia: Tiffin carrier":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiffin_carrier]

title: lunchbox
body:
A small [[box]] filled with prepared food to eat at [[lunch]].

Not to be confused with [[bento]], as lunchbox typically comes in a single box and may contains any kinds of food, while bento is often stacked into a tower or having its contents filled with Japanese food.

h4. Types

* [[American lunchbox]]
* [[Dome lunchbox]]
* [[Tiffin carrier]]

h4.See also

* [[bento]]
* [[Tag Group:Food Tags]]

title: american_lunchbox
body:
A rectangular metal or plastic [[lunchbox]] that was prevalent especially in North America and targeted toward school children.  With the handle and latch at the top and a hinge at the bottom, you'd have to lay the lunchbox on its side when opening it.  As these were typically targeted at children, they would frequently feature artwork on the sides.  Many shows and movies as part of their merchandising would have such lunchboxes made featuring art and images of characters.  Vintage metal lunchboxes with such promotional art are frequently a collectible item in North America.

h4. See also

* [[Dome lunchbox]]

h4. External links

* "Wikipedia: Lunchbox in the United States":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lunchbox#In_the_United_States]

title: dome_lunchbox
body:
A metal [[lunchbox]] with a shape similar to a rounded-top home [[mailbox (incoming mail)|]].  This type of lunchbox featured a large rounded top with a handle.  The top was affixed to the base by a hinge and inside the top you could store a [[thermos]] bottle for drinks.  Frequently tied in the past with the imagery of working laborers, such as construction workers, in North America.

h4. See also

* [[American lunchbox]]

title: master_emerald
body:
The large, green gemstone watched over by [[Knuckles the Echidna]]. Its power keeps his homeplace, Angel Island, afloat in the sky.
The God of Destruction, [[chaos_(sonic)|Chaos]], was sealed inside it along with [[tikal_the_echidna|Tikal]] following the destruction of the Knuckles Clan. The emerald has the power of cancelling the effect of the seven smaller [[chaos_emerald|Chaos Emeralds]]. If it shatters, Knuckles is capable of sensing its pieces and placing them back together.

title: mayreel_(guardian_tales)
body:
Divine beast of harvest Mayreel a.k.a Mayreel is the god of harvest Kamael's divine beast, an alpaca with the power of grass and flowers. Usually, she tags along with Bari in her alpaca form, but she can change into human form.

She's a pessimist who hates almost everything. She dislikes everyone, even including the god of harvest Kamael. She does appreciate that Kamael raised her with love and care, but she can't help rolling her eyes at Kamael's relentless "nagging" at her. Kamael hopes Mayreel to look at him the way she twinkles her eyes at Bari, but Mayreel would rather spit out on the ground and demand him not to bother her. How sad it is for Kamael when there seems to be no end to Mayreel's rebellious phase.

Mayreel hates humans. She can never understand why Bari willingly helps those greedy humans; sometimes even consuming her own happy memories. There was a time when Mayreel used to like humans since anyone who set their eyes on Mayreel would immediately fall in love with her adorable figure. But a long time ago, some crowd of people abused Bari's compassion and wished for outrageous things wasting Bari's memory. If Mayreel did not punish them on time, Bari would have not even remembered Mayreel and Kamael. Since then Mayreel became wary of humans to protect Bari from the selfish species.

Mayreel hates her human form. She constantly whines about how it's uncomfortable and cumbersome to be in a human form, about how many customs she has to uphold. That's probably why she looks so annoyed and wears her priest outfit sloppily when Bari asks her to turn into her human form. Bari tidies up Mayreel's outfit whenever she can, but in a blink of a second Mayreel will untidy her clothes. Although she, certainly, is a handful, Bari stills love the way she is.

title: movie_star_eugene
body:
Eugene is a movie star in Burywood.

Before she made her way into the stardom, she endured long and arduous period as a stunt double. She got her lucky break when the quirky director Vale discovered her for the action film "Bat Queen." The movie was an instant box office hit. She continued to work with Vale on "Queensman" which was another instant hit.

Her career dwindled when she signed a contract with the infamous Invader Pictures, Inc. She had constant clash with the studio while shooting the film "War of Stars." The movie was eventually cancelled and her streak seemed to be over as well. Her career revived when she rejoined with Vale for the indie film "Guardian Story" where she played a young aspiring guardian.

Due to her roles as heroes, she has cemented her image as an honest and righteous hero. However, Eugene mentioned in one interview that she actually enjoys B rated gore/kaiju films and that she would love to play a villain.

She is known to be a very positive and hard working person. Because of her prolonged stunt career she is extremely durable, a master of various weapons, and an expert bike rider.

title: flower_girl_bari
body:
Bari is a high priestess of the god of harvest. Her mission is to resurrect the burnt world tree by collecting happy memories from people.

Bari grants you one wish and takes your happiest memory away in return. The greater the wish, the bigger chunk of memories it'll cost. Bari always tries to remain distant to her clients to avoid getting involved with humans but often fails due to her compassionate nature. When she sees someone desperately in need but does not have enough happy memories, she chips in her own memory to grant the wish. You should not get frustrated if she doesn't remember you - it just means she cherished the memory with you and passed the happiness to another in need.

She has two rules when granting wishes. One - if her client becomes greedy and attempts to exploit her, she will make sure the client pay for the sin whether it's by her own hand or by curse of mother nature. Two - she won't bring anyone back from dead. It always made clients' lives worse.
other_names: バリ(ガーディアンテイルズ)

title: american_le_mans_series
body:
A now-defunct American [[car]] [[racing]] motorsports series, created in 1999 as a successor to the [[IMSA GT Championship]]. As the name implies, ALMS was designed to bring [[circuit de la sarthe|Le Mans]] style racing to American and Canadian tracks, featuring endurance races with [[Le Mans prototype]]s and GT [[racecar]]s.

The American Le Mans series had it's final season in 2013 after a merger with [[Grand-Am Road Racing]], with the new [[IMSA SportsCar Championship]] taking it's place in 2014.
other_names: アメリカン・ル・マン・シリーズ

title: naginata
body:
A Japanese [[weapon]] composed of a long pole and a curved blade at the end. It is similar to the Chinese [[guan dao]] or the European [[glaive (polearm)|]]. title: e-123_omega
body:
A character in the [[sonic_(series)|Sonic the Hedgehog]] series. The last known member of the E-100 Series of robots created by [[Dr. Eggman]]. A bulky red and black [[robot]] with the omega (Ω) symbol on his shoulder.

Omega first appeared in [[Sonic Heroes]]. He was deployed inside a secret laboratory with the purpose of guarding a capsule that contained [[Shadow the Hedgehog]]. 
Omega serves as the Power type character in Team Dark since [[Rouge the Bat]] convinced him to form a team with her and a then-amnesiac Shadow to search after Eggman. He is known to hold a long-standing hatred for his creator and his other robots.

body:

Information about her from artist;
https://twitter.com/ZA1F0N/status/1646967584485707776

[quote]Description:
An eldritch hivemind of shadowy creatures that have taken the form of a dapper dressed lady. 

Born from the literal tears of the Gremlin creature from the void known as Zaifon.

Likes: Green tea, memes, suits and dress up.

Dislikes: Being the parent of the parent.


Additional Notes:
Abby's void body looks like a shadowy silhouette, but on closer inspection, their skin(?) is actually made of black tendrils and eyes that are consistently moving above the surface.

So the eyes and texture positions on their body is not consistent.[/quote]

title: fuji_speedway
body:

title: new_zealand
body:
An island country in the southwestern Pacific Ocean. It consists of two main landmasses the North Island (Te Ika-a-Māui) and the South Island (Te Waipounamu), and over 700 smaller islands. Owing to their remoteness, the islands of New Zealand were the last large habitable landmass to be settled by humans. Between about 1280 and 1350, Polynesians began to settle in the islands and then developed a distinctive [[maori|Māori]] culture.
Additionally New Zealand's mountain ranges, wild rivers and grassy fields provided the perfect setting for the [[The lord of the rings|Lord of the Rings]] movie trilogy.
